item.name: 1754: Conquest – The French and Indian War
1776: The Game of the American Revolutionary War
1812: The Campaign of Napoleon in Russia
1914: Twilight in the East – Dragoni Variant
1918: Operation Michel, Germany's Last Chance in the West
1944: Second Front – From D-Day to Victory in the West
221B Baker St.: Sherlock Holmes & the Time Machine
221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game
48th Panzer Korps: Battles on the River Chir
Acquire
item.comment:
This game is easy to learn/teach and plays in 1-2 hours. It's not my favorite game, but I'm always willing to play.
We used to play with open knowledge of stock holdings, but our last game holdings were kept secret. I feel this adds more excitement to the game.

item.name: Across Suez: The Battle of the Chinese Farm October 15, 1973
Across The Narva: The Soviet Assault on Estonia, February 1944
Advanced Squad Leader: Starter Kit #4 – Pacific Theater of Operations
Advanced Squad Leader: Starter Kit Bonus Pack #2
Advanced Squad Leader: Starter Kit Expansion Pack #1
Advanced Squad Leader: Starter Kit Expansion Pack #2
Advanced Tobruk System Basic Game I: Infantry
The African Campaign: Designer Signature Edition
Afrika Korps: The Desert War – Platoon Level Combat in World War II: A Panzer Grenadier Game
After the Holocaust: The Nuclear Devastation of America – Recovery and Reunification
Air Bridge to Victory: Operation Market-Garden, 1944
All is lost save Honour: Campaigns of the Italian Wars 1494-1530 – Vol.1
All Is Lost to Me: Pavia 1525
All Quiet on the Western Front
America Triumphant: The Battle of the Bulge
The American Revolution: Decision in North America
April's Harvest: The Battle of Shiloh, April 6 & 7, 1862
¡Apuren el corralito!: The 2nd Battle of Alihuatá, December 1933
Arctic Front: Finland's War, 1939-1944 – A Panzer Grenadier Scenario Book
Ardennes '44: The Battle of the Bulge
Ariete: The Battle of Bir el Gubi, Libya November 1941
At All Hazards: The Cold Harbor Campaign
The Atlanta Campaign: Bald Hill and Ezra Church
The Atlanta Campaign: Peachtree Creek & Jonesboro
Avalanche: The Invasion of Italy
item.comment: Interesting game system that, while not complex given the number of units in the game, is not a light play.

item.name: Avec Honneur et Panache: Volume 1 – Turenne
Axis & Allies Miniatures
item.comment: Don't buy this for the game, it sucks. The rules seem almost an afterthought. However, the minis very cool and worth every penny. Just track down a different set of rules.

item.name: The Balkan Wars: Prelude to Disaster, 1912-1913
BANG!
item.comment:
I love a game where you can shoot people and laugh doing it. This is a great end of the day game. Only problems is you need a good number of players -- at least 5 or 6, but more is better -- to enjoy this game.
UPDATE: Yes, it's fun, but there's only so many times you can shoot someone and still find it enjoyable. Downgraded from an 8 to a 7.

item.name: Baptism By Fire: The Battle of Kasserine
Barbarossa: Army Group Center, 1941 – Second Edition
Bastogne: Screaming Eagles Under Siege 18-27 Dec' 44
Baton Rouge: Street Fighting in the Louisiana Capital, August 5, 1862
Battle Cry
item.comment:
A great simple game to play with non-wargamers. It's short enough that playing 2 out of 3 matches is feasible, which is great because luck can really kill you in this game.
UPDATE: Since this release of Memoire '44 and C&C: Ancients, this game comes off the worse in a comparison. Being dealt a bad hand can kill you worse than in the other games. And what's with the lack of defensive fire?

item.name: The Battle for Cassino: Assaulting the Gustav Line, 1944
The Battle for North Africa: War in the Desert, 1940-42
The Battle of Guilford Courthouse: The Beginning of the End
Battle of the Bulge: Platoon Level Combat in World War II – A Panzer Grenadier Game
Battlelines: The Stalingrad Campaign
item.comment:
Combines with best of CCGs (rules determined by cards in play) while leaving out the worst (you get all cards for a set in one purchase).
The rules, however, are horrible! They need a serious re-write. And the cards are way too busy. That said, once I finally realized how the game is played, I enjoyed in immensely. I will play this game often.
UPDATE: I have since sold off this game. There are some good ideas, but I just couldn't get into the overall idea. Also, the dearth of opponants didn't help. I would still say it's worth exploring for people who like the topics.

item.name: Battles of the Ancient World: Marathon and Granicus
Beyond the Beaches: ASL Starter Kit Bonus Pack #1
Beyond the Rhine: The Campaign for Northwest Europe
The Big Push: The Battle of the Somme
Bitter Victory: The Invasion of Sicily, 1943
Black Death
item.comment: I really wanted to like this game. The historical topic fascinates me and my humor is sick enough that the concept is appealing. However, there's just not enough there. I feel like the game is playing me.

item.name: The Blitzkrieg Legend: The Battle for France, 1940
Blood on the Snow: The Battle of Suomussalmi
Blood Reef: Tarawa – ASL Historical Module 5
Bloodiest Day: The Battle of Antietam September 17, 1862
Bloody April: The Battle of Shiloh, 1862
Bloody Roads South: The Battle of the Wilderness May 5-7, 1864 – The South's Last Chance
Blue vs. Gray
item.comment: This is unlike any other wargame I own. There is barely any movement on the map and yet large armies are marching across the United States. I've only played it once, so I still have to absorb some of the mechanics and how to execute them.

item.name: The Bottle Imp
item.comment: Eh? I don't know. If I want to play cards, Spades are Hearts are good enough.

item.name: Brandy Station: Cavalry vs Cavalry, June 1863
Bull Run: The First Major Battle of the American Civil War
Burma: The Campaign in Northern Burma, 1944
Cactus Throne: The Mexican War of 1862-1867
CAESAR: The Great Battles of Julius Caesar – The Civil Wars 48-45 B.C.
Campaign for Guadalcanal: Long Lance & Henderson Field
Canadian Crucible: Brigade Fortress at Norrey
Car Wars Supplements: The AADA Road Atlas and Survival Guides
Carcassonne
item.comment: I came into this game thinking Very Clever Pipe Game, but was decieved. The scoring is still a puzzle I'm working out: farmers permanantly tie up a meeple, but seem to be vital in wracking up the points. This is a great game when you don't have time for a longer one (such as Settlers or Puerto Rico), but it's much more than a filler for between games. I am always willing to play this game.

item.name: Carthage: The First Punic War – The Ancient World, Vol. II
CATAN
item.comment: What a wonderfully easy game to get into. There are a small number of decisions to make, but they are tough to make. My one beef with this game is the extremes in the dice can make or break you AND it is possible to go a turn or two with nothing or little to do (cf., dice extremes). HOWEVER, I am always willing to play a game.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: I did enjoy this game the one time I've played it, enough for me to have purchased a copy. HOWEVER, there is a lot going on here. I felt overwhelmed by the number and complexity of decisions. It will take me a several more plays before I feel comfortable with it. Something I'm more than willing to do and will probably update my rating.

item.name: Cedar Mountain: Prelude to Bull Run, August 9, 1862
Central Command: Superpower Confrontation in the Straits of Hormuz
Champion Hill: May 16th, 1863 – The Road to Vicksburg
Chosin: X Corps Escapes the Trap
Civil War Classics, Volume 1: The Battles of Pea Ridge & Shiloh
Clash of Empires: The Battle for France 1914
Clash of Giants II: 1st Ypres & Galicia 1914
Clash of Giants: Campaigns of Tannenberg and the Marne, 1914
Clash of the Eagles: Borodino & Friedland
Clash of the Gladiators
item.comment: This game fills a good niche: it's silly and short. I'm still trying to figure out the relative worth of some gladiator types and have been experimenting with extremes (All swords, 3 sheilds and 1 sword, etc.). This is a great game to end a session or fill the gaps between meatier games.

item.name: Clash of Titans: The Tank Battle for Kursk, 1943
Cobra: Game of the Normandy Breakout
Combined Arms: Rules for WWII Infantry-Armour Actions
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #1 – Greece & Eastern Kingdoms
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #2 – Rome vs the Barbarians
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #3 – The Roman Civil Wars
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #4 – Imperial Rome
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #5 – Epic Ancients II
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #6 – The Spartan Army
Cortes: Conquest of the Aztec Empire
The Cossacks Are Coming!: The Tannenberg Campaign August and September, 1914 – 2nd Edition
Cromwell's Victory: The Battle of Marston Moor
Crossing the Line: Aachen 1944
item.comment:
I played and loved the original many years ago. This is a beautiful new version. I did not see any substantive changes to the rules.
While I recommend this game, I do have some issues: * While the artwork is beautiful, there's insufficient contrast between the units and the map, and between the Germans and the Americans. * Support only helps the attacker, not the defender. Why can't that artillery and other units help out in defense? This is not a change from the original and I cannot remember it bothering me back in the day. I chalk that up to maturity.

item.name: Crusader: The 8th Army's Winter Victory, Nov-Dec 1941
Cudgel Duel: Franco's first counterstrikes at the Ebro, Aug-Sep 1938
DAK2: The Campaign in North Africa, 1940-1942
Dark Victory: The Battle of the Alamo
Day of Days: The Invasion of Normandy 1944
Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Dead of Winter: The Battle of Stones River – Murfreesboro, Tennessee
Dead of Winter: The Battle of Stones River (Second Edition)
Death in the Trenches: The Great War, 1914-1918
DeathMaze: Heroic Adventure in the Corridors of Doom
Decision at Elst: An Advanced Squad Leader Starter Kit Historical Module
Decision at Kasserine: Rommel's Last Chance – Designer Signature Edition
Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment:
My oldest is interested in D&D (she's 11), but we don't have others to play. This game fits the bill. My only complaint is the time it takes to complete a game. We have yet to do one in a single sitting.
I'm traking down some "real" hallways and rooms from Dwarven Forge as well as minis from Wizards of the Coast to make this more lifelike.

item.name: The Desert Fox: Rommel's Campaign for North Africa April 1941-December 1942
Desert Storm: The Mother of All Battles
Destruction of Army Group Center: The Soviet Summer Offensive, 1944
The Devil's Cauldron: The Battles for Arnhem and Nijmegen
The Devil's Horsemen: The Battle of Liegnitz
Diadochoi: Great Battles of Alexander Module
Dixie: The Second War Between the States
Don't Tread on Me: The American Revolution Solitaire Board Game
Down in Flames Squadron Pack 1: Fighters
Down in Flames Squadron Pack 2: Bombers
Downfall: If the U.S. Invaded Japan, 1945
Drive on Washington: The Battle of Monocacy Junction, July 9, 1864
Duel in the Desert: Rommel's Campaign in North Africa
Eastwall: Battles for the Dnepr, September 1943 - February 1944
Edelweiss: A Panzer Grenadier Scenario Book
Edelweiss: The Struggle in the Caucasus, 1942
Embrace an Angry Wind: The Battles of Spring Hill & Franklin, 29-30 November 1864
End of Empire: The French and Indian War and the American Revolution
Fallen Eagle: The Battle of Khe Sanh, Vietnam, 1968
Fallschirmjaeger: The Airborne Assault on Fortress Holland
The Fate of Reiters: Five Battles of the French Wars of Religion
Fateful Lightning
item.comment:
Pretty good regimental scale ACW game. I like how combat is resolved, that the game is pretty fast moving despite its size, and very few markers. I have a bit of a problem with how a small number of very important die rolls (army initiative and turn end) can skew the game if there are extreme runs
I will play this game again

item.name: Fields of Battle Volume 1, The Great Northern War
Fifth Corps: The Soviet Breakthrough at Fulda
Fire in the Sky: The Great Pacific War 1941-1945
First Blood: The 1st and 2nd Battles of Manassas
Flintlock: Black Powder, Cold Steel - Volume I: Carolina Rebels
Formula Dé Circuits 13 & 14: Montreal & Long Beach
Formula Dé Circuits 23 - 26: USA Track Pack #1
France 1944: The Allied Crusade in Europe
The Franco-Prussian War: August 1 to September 2, 1870
The French & Indian War: Struggle for the New World
Fulda Gap: The First Battle of the Next War
Gaines Mill: The Battles of the Seven Days, June 1962, Volume 1
A Game of Thrones Collectible Card Game
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
A Gleam of Bayonets: The Battle of Antietam
Glory Road: The First Battle of Bull Run
The Great Battles of Alexander: Deluxe Edition
The Great Battles of Julius Caesar: The Civil Wars 48-45 B.C. – Dictator
The Great Battles of Julius Caesar: The Civil Wars 48-45 B.C. – Veni Vidi Vici: The Battles of Nicopolis 48 B.C. Zela 47 B.C.
Great Medieval Battles: The Battles of Bannockburn and Angorra
The Great War in Europe: Deluxe Edition
The Great War in the East: 1914-1918 (Second Edition)
The Great War in the Near East
Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere: War in Asia and the Pacific
The Greatest Day: Sword, Juno, and Gold Beaches
A Greek Tragedy: The Italian Invasion of Greece 1940-1941
Gunslinger
item.comment: Please shoot me before I play this game again. Mind numbingly slow.

item.name: Gustav Adolf the Great: With God and Victorious Arms
Harvest of Death: The Second Day at Gettysburg
Hell Before Night: The Battle of Shiloh
Heroes of the Soviet Union: The Defense of Mother Russia 1942-43
Highway to the Reich: The Allied Airborne Invasion of Holland, 1944 (Third Edition)
Hoorah! Six Bridges: The Battle of Pittsburgh, 1 October 1863
The Horse Soldiers: Forrest at Bay
A House Divided: War Between the States 1861-65
How to Host a Murder: The Duke's Descent
Huarikasaya Kalatakaya!: The battle of Strongest, Bolivia vs Paraguay, May 1934.
Hungarian Rhapsody: The Eastern Front in Hungary
Imperial
item.comment: Interesting game with hints of Acquire in it. The conplexity arises in that what helps you very often will also help your opponent(s).

item.name: In the Trenches: Through Mud and Blood
In their Quiet Fields II
item.comment: I'm a big fan of The Gamers' Civil War Brigade Series. The rules, while seemingly complex, are fairly straight forward. You will not want to play this with a rules lawyer as the orders system is someone subjective. ITQF is somewhat limited in the option it present users; there will be no tactical finessing. However, it is still fun.

item.name: Iron Tide: Panzers in the Ardennes
Island of Death: Invasion of Malta, 1942
Ivanhoe
item.comment: A game with a seemingly simple premise: be the one to play the most points for a particular color. However, there are so many nuances, that I could play this game forever.

item.name: Iwo Jima: Rage Against the Marines
Iwo Jima: Valor of Arms, 19 Feb. – 25 March 1945
Jackson at the Crossroads: Cross Keys & Port Republic, June 8-9, 1862
The Jaws of Victory: Battle of Korsun-Cherkassy Pocket – January/February 1944
The Kaiser's Battle: The German Offensive, March 1918
Kanev: Parachutes Across the Dnepr, September 23-26, 1943
Karelia '44: The Last Campaign of the Continuation War
Kawaguchi's Gamble: Edson's Ridge – The Battle for Guadalcanal
Khan: The Rise of the Mongol Empire, A.D. 1206-1295
Kiev & Rostov: Battles of Army Group South, 1941
Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot
Königsberg: The Soviet Attack on East Prussia, 1945
Korsun Pocket 2: Little Stalingrad on the Dnepr
Krim: von Manstein's Battles for Sevastopol, 1941-1942
Kung Fu Fighting
item.comment: OK, this is not the best game I've ever played. I enjoy challenging my kids, though. Carl Douglas must be playing in the background.

item.name: Land of the Free: American Politics During the Depression
Land Without End: The Barbarossa Campaign, 1941
Last Blitzkrieg: Wacht am Rhein, The Battle of the Bulge
Last Chance for Victory: The Battle of Gettysburg
The Last Crusade: The Battle of Nicopolis – September 25, 1396
Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
The Last Victory: Von Manstein's Backhand Blow
Lebensraum: The Campaign in the East, 1941-1945
Lee vs. Grant: The Wilderness Campaign of 1864
Lest Darkness Fall: Rome in Crisis, AD 235 – 285
Lightning: D-Day
item.comment: Ugh, what a waste of money. What's the point? Once a player gets a leg up, it's all over.

item.name: The Little Land: The Battle of Novorossiysk
Little Round Top: The South's Best Chance at Gettysburg
The Lord of the Rings Adventure Book Game
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment:
This is a fascinating, quick playing game that is all skill. You know what options your opponant has. He know that you know that he knows that... The decisions are small in number, but they have a huge repurcussion. This is my all time favorite game.
UPDATE: This is still one of my favorites, but the bloom as somewhat come off the rose.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
Lord of the Rings: The Search
The Lost Battalion: The Meuse-Argonne Offensive, 1918
item.comment: Playable operational World War One games are few and far between. This was enjoyable as a solitaire effort, but it's nothing I'd get worked up over to play again. I love the concepts of the machine nests. And the brutally bloody combat combined with the generous (for the Americans, anyways) replacements keeps the game humming along. I would like to see other battles done with this system.

item.name: Lost Victory: Manstein At Kharkov, Winter 1943
Luftwaffe: The Game of Aerial Combat Over Germany 1943-45
Malvern Hill: The Battles of the Seven Days, Volume III
Mamma Mia!
item.comment: I felt this game was playing me. I suppose I might try it again, but only if there's nothing better to do.

item.name: The Marcher Lords: The Norman Conquest of Wales
Marignan 1515: la chevauchée de François 1er en Italie
Marlborough: War of the Spanish Succession
Mason-Dixon: The Second American Civil War
Matanikau: Battles on the Matanikau River, Guadalcanal, 1942
Memoir '44
item.comment: This is much better than Battle Cry, but not as good as Command & Colors: Ancients. You can still be killed by the cards, but there's more variety and options in this game. And the figures are cool. I need to get enough Axis & Allies Minis to use them with this game.

item.name: Moscow Burning: The Next Russian Civil War
Mr. Lincoln's War: Army of the Potomac
Mr. Madison's War: The Incredible War of 1812
Mukden: Climax of the Russo-Japanese War
Napoleon and the Archduke Charles: The Battle of Aspern-Essling
Napoleon's Art of War: Eylau & Dresden
Ney vs. Wellington: The Battle of Quatre Bras
No Better Place to Die: The Battle of Murfreesboro
No Prisoners: The Campaigns of Lawrence of Arabia, 1915-1918
No Question of Surrender: The Battle for Bir Hacheim
Nothing So Well Lost: The Siege of Rhodes 1522
Objective: Kiev (The Advance of Army Group South: June-August, 1941)
October War: Doctrine and Tactics in the Yom Kippur Conflict, 1973
Oil War: American Intervention in the Persian Gulf
Omaha Beachhead: Battle for the Bocage
Operation Crusader: The 8th Army's Forgotten Victory
Operation Dauntless: The Battles for Fontenay and Rauray, France, June 1944
Operation Grenade: The Battle for the Rhineland 23 Feb. - 5 Mar. '45
Operation Mercury: The German Airborne Assault on Crete, 1941
Operation Mercury: The Invasion of Crete
Operation Skorpion: Rommel's First Strike – Halfaya Pass, May 1941
Operation Spark: the Relief of Leningrad 1943
Operation Typhoon: The German Assault on Moscow, 1941
Osmanli Harbi: The Ottoman Fronts – 1914 to 1918
The Ottomans: Rise of the Turkish Empire, 1453-1571
Over the Top! Four Battles from World War One
Over the Top! Mons & The Marne
Overlord: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles
Pacific Battles: Volume 1, The Rising Sun
Pacific War Classics Vol 1: Tarawa & Saipan
The Pacific War: From Pearl Harbor to the Philippines
Panzer Battles: 11th Panzer on the Chir River
Panzer Battles: Tactical Armored Warfare in World War II
Panzer Command: The Gateway to Stalingrad
Panzer Leader: Game of Tactical Warfare on the Western Front
PanzerArmee Afrika: Rommel in the Desert, April 1941 - November 1942
PanzerBlitz: Hill of Death – The Battle for Hill 112, Normandy 1944
Panzers Last Stand: Battles for Budapest, 1945
Par le feu, le fer et la Foi
Paris vaut bien une Messe! Les Guerres de Religion 1562-1598
Paths of Glory
item.comment:
An excellent and enjoyable game. I like the puzzle that is what order to play your cards as well as what manner. It is also very easy to PBeM. In fact, I have never played this game ftf.
HOWEVER, this game is not history. Because it is so scripted, it can easily veer off into absurdity. For example, the Russians could be steam-rolling the Austro-Hungarians, but because the Allied player needs to get to Total War, he'll play The Great Retreat even though he knows he'll not be retreating even one space in the forseeable future.
Ah, but it is such a great game.

item.name: Paths to Hell: Operation Barbarossa, June – December 1941
Paul Koenig's D-Day: Juno – The Canadian Beach
Paul Koenig's D-Day: Utah and Omaha – The American Beaches
Pavia: Climax of the Italian Wars
Pea Ridge: St Louis, then Huzzah!
Pea Ridge: The Gettysburg of the West March 7-8 1862
Pegasus Bridge: The Beginning of D-Day – June 6, 1944
Perfidious Albion: Napoleon's (Hypothetical) Invasion of England, 1814
Phalanx: Great Battles of Alexander Module
Piercing the Reich: The Battle for Aachen, Siegfried Line Campaign, Sep-Oct 1944
Pleasant Hill: The Red River Campaign
Poison
item.comment: Not a bad filler game. Interesting choices to be made regarding which pot to fill. I'd be willing to play again.

item.name: Poland Defiant: The German Invasion, September 1939
Port Stanley: Battle for the Falklands
Power Grid
item.comment: Love the game: the interaction between capacity and what you can power up. There's a small number of decisions, but they are tough ones to make. I will play this again.

item.name: Prelude to Disaster: The Soviet Spring Offensive
The Price of Freedom: The American Civil War 1861-1865
The Princess Bride Adventure Book Game
Proud Monster: The Barbarossa Campaign – Death & Destruction: The Russian Front 1942-44
Prussia's Glory II: Four Battles of the Seven Years War, 1757-1759
Prussia's Glory: The Battles of Frederick the Great
Puerto Rico
item.comment: This is my new favorite game. The number and complexity of the decisions can be overwhelming, but after a few plays, the proper strategy is coming into focus. I like that every player is always doing something. I also like the indirect conflict among the players: when to select which role, what to sell/ship/buy, etc. I want to play this game right now!

item.name: The Punic Wars: The Struggle for the Mediterranean, 264-146 BC
Quartermaster General: Victory or Death – The Peloponnesian War
Raid! Commando Operations, in the 20th Century
Rattenkrieg: Assault on the Tracktor Factory
Rebel Sabers: Civil War Cavalry Battles
Red Army: The Destruction of Army Group Center
Red God of War: The Soviet Operation Mars, 1942
Red Parachutes: Soviet Airborne Assault Across the Dnepr
Red Star Rising: The War in Russia, 1941-1944
Red Steel: Clash Of Armor At Kishinev
item.comment:
The rules read well. I really wanted to like this game since battalion level WW2 games are one of my sweet spots, but this game is a bit painful to play. The combat sequence alone has 18 steps.
That said, if I can pass my morale check in the future. I want to try it again.

item.name: Red Storm over the Reich: The Last Days of the Third Reich
Red Typhoon: The Soviet Winter Counter-Offensive, 1942
Revolt in the East: Warsaw Pact Rebellion in the 1970's
Ring of Fire: The Fourth Battle for Kharkov, August 1943
Rio Grande: The Battle of Valverde
The Rise of the Roman Republic
Risorgimento 1859: the Second Italian War of Independence
River of Death: Battle of Chickamauga, September 19-20, 1863
Roads to Moscow: Battles of Mozhaysk and Mtsensk, 1941
item.comment: I wanted to like this game. WW2 battalion scale is my sweet spot and there are not enough games on early East Front battles. But the die rolling, damn! Each battle can involve 9 or more die rolls! To what end? Generating chaos? Defeating the player's omniscience? There's got to be a better way

item.name: Rome at War II: Fading Legions
Rough & Ready: Opening Battles of the Mexican-American War
The Russian Campaign: Southern Expansion Kit
Ruweisat Ridge: The First Battle of El Alamein
Salerno: The 1943 Allied Invasion of Italy
Screaming Eagles in Holland: The 101st Airborne Division's Defense of Hell's Highway, 22-23 September, 1944
Serbia the Defiant / Romania: Transylvanian Gambit
Shifting Sands: The Campaign for North Africa 1940-1943
Shining Path: The Struggle for Peru
Shogun
item.comment: Love this game! I never had a chance to play Wallenstein, but I'm told this is as good. I love the combat resolution with the infamous tower.

item.name: ShowBiz Shuffle
item.comment: A great game to fill the time between more serious fare. Half the fun is in describing the movie you've just made or dis-ing your opponent for a low scoring romance.

item.name: The Siege of Alesia: Gaul, 52 B.C.
Sixth Fleet: US/Soviet Naval Operations in the Mediterranean in the 1970's
Smithereens: The End of World War II in Europe
Soldiers of the Queen: Battles at Isandhlwana and Omdurman
Some Poles Apart: The Battle of the Westerplatte
South Africa: The Death of Colonialism
Spanish Civil War Battles: Vol. 1 – Brunete & Jarama
Spanish Civil War Battles: Vol. 2 – Guadalajara & Penarroya
Spartacus: Crisis in the Roman Republic 80-71 B.C.
Stalingrad Pocket: 2nd Edition – The Wehrmacht's Greatest Disaster
Stand & Die: The Battle of Borodino, 1941
Stonewall's Last Battle: The Chancellorsville Campaign
Strafexpedition 1916
item.comment: This game matches well with my ideas about how a wargame should simulate a historical event. It implements the inertia and entropy typical to such events. My only complaints are with physical design. The formation a counter belongs to can be difficult to discern and the map gets congested in places

item.name: Strange Defeat: The Fall of France, 1940
Strike Them a Blow: 1864 North Anna River
Striking the Anvil: Operation Anvil Dragoon
Struggle of Empires
item.comment: I love the combat system as well as how unrest/money is used. I would play this one regularly if I could just gather the requisite number of players.

item.name: Sucking Vacuum
item.comment: It was funny the one time I've played it. I can't see myself playing it again, though. No real decisions to make.

item.name: Summer Storm: The Battle of Gettysburg
The Sun Never Sets: Three Campaigns of the British Empire
Sunrise of Victory: The 1942 Campaign in Russia
Supply Lines of the American Revolution: The Northern Theater, 1775-1777
Supply Lines of the American Revolution: The Southern Strategy
Sword of Rome: Conquest of Italy, 362-272 BC
item.comment: Interesting game on a topic I am not familiar with. The only game I have played was with the 5th player expansion, I can't imagine playing without it. This game was unusual as compared to other card driven wargames I've played in that I did not cycle through the deck very many times (just twice, I believe). I am willing to play this again, but need more experience before I can pass final judgement.

item.name: Swords & Sorcery: Quest and Conquest in the Age of Magic
Tank Battles: A Panzer Grenadier Scenario Book
Tannenberg and the Opening Battles in the East 1914
Tannenberg: Eagles in the East / Galicia: The Forgotten Cauldron
The Ten Thousand: The Battle of Cunaxa, 401 BC
Terrible Swift Sword: Battle of Gettysburg Game
They Died With Their Boots On, Volume 1: Custer's Last Stand
The Third Winter: The Battle for the Ukraine September 1943-April 1944
Thirty Years War: Europe in Agony, 1618-1648
Thunder at the Crossroads: The Battle of Gettysburg, July 1-3, 1863 (Second Edition)
Thunder in the Ozarks: Battle for Pea Ridge, March 1862
Ticket to Ride
item.comment: A great game for the whole family. The concepts are simple enough for children around 8 years of age to pick up, but the decisions to be made are tough enough to keep adults interested. This is current THE game my family plays.

item.name: Ticonderoga: The Battles for Lake George, 1755-1758
Tinian: The Forgotten Battle
item.comment:
I want to like this game. Company level WW2 is a sweet spot for me. But this game misses on several levels. There are FAR too many markers that cause Everestian sized stacks. And the pace seems really slow.
The faults might be because this is an island invasion with no primary armor units. I'd be willing to try another title

item.name: Tiny Epic Quest: Quest for the Golden Mushrooms
Tito and his Partisan Army: Yugoslavia, 1941-45
To Take Washington: Jubal Early's Summer 1864 Campaign
To the Green Fields Beyond: The Battle of Cambrai, 1917
Tokyo Express: The Guadalcanal Naval Campaign – 1942
Toppling the Reich: The Battles for the Westwall
Totaler Krieg! Player's Guide & Expansion Kit
Trial of Strength: War on the Eastern Front 1941-45
Triumph & Glory: Battles of the Napoleonic Wars 1796-1809
Triumphant Fox: Rommel's Finest Hour – The Gazala Battles May-June 1942
Triumphant Return: The Soviet Liberation of Kiev, November 1943
Twilight Struggle
item.comment: Having played quite a few card driven wargames, it took me a while to get into this one. There are no armies on the map! Once I got over that seemingly obvious issue, I really go into this game. There are a myriad of choices each turn beyond the typical operations/event options typical to games in this genre. I will buy this and play it often.

item.name: Tyrant: Battles of Carthage versus Syracuse
Valor of the Guards: ASL Historical Module Number 7
Victory at Midway: Turning Point of the Pacific War, June 1942
A Victory Complete: The Battle of Tannenberg, 1914
A Victory Denied: Crisis at Smolensk, July-September, 1941
Victory in the West: Plan Yellow, The French Campaign 1940
A Victory Lost: Crisis in Ukraine 1942-1943
item.comment: Wargame nirvana: easy to learn, fast to set up, plays in one session, and different enough each to time warrent replay.

item.name: Vietnam Battles: Hue and Operation Pegasus
'Wacht am Rhein': The Battle of the Bulge, 16 Dec 44 – 2 Jan 45
Wahoo! The Battle of Washington July 8, 1863
The Walking Dead: The Board Game
War in the Ice: The Battle for the Seventh Continent, 1991-92
War of the Ring: The Card Game
War of the States: Chickamauga & Chattanooga
War of the Triple Alliance: Paraguay – 1865-1870
We the People
item.comment:
This is the simplest of the card driven wargames. It's easy to learn and plays quickly. And it provides a narrative that closely resembles the history. HOWEVER, the cards can kill you more easily in this game than any other card driven game I've played. It is possible to draw a hand which contains no playable cards whatsoever. Extreme timing of certain events -- such as Declaration of Independence -- can also kill the game.
I still like playing it, though. Becuase it is over quickly, you can usually get in a rematch in the same session.

item.name: Where Eagles Dare: The Battle for Hell's Highway
White Death: Velikiye Luki, The Stalingrad of the North
The Wilderness
item.comment: This is a brigade-level, grand tactical game where artillery fire is resolved on an odds-based CRT. That's a deal breaker for me

item.name: Wilson's Creek: The West's First Fight, August 10, 1861
World War I: 1914-1918
item.comment:
I don't get this games popularity. There are many problems with it: The Balkans don't matter, ZOC craziness, and that the CP can fall back to avoid combat.
There are a number of house rules that MIGHT rescue this. I'll play this if someone really, really wants to.

item.name: World War II: Barbarossa to Berlin
Yalu: The Chinese Counteroffensive in Korea: November 1950-May 1951 (Second Edition)
Yom Kippur: The Battle for the Sinai, October, 1973
